author Photoredox dual reaction of organic synthesis and H2 evolution opens up a novel pathway for collaboratively generating clean fuels and high-quality chemicals, providing a more effective approach of solar energy conversion. Herein, a surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS heterostructure with zinc blende (ZB)/wurtzite (WZ) phase junctions is synthesized for photocatalytic cooperative coupling of benzaldehyde (BAD) and H2 production. This surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS heterostructure elaborately integrates the mixed phase junction advantage of ZnCdS semiconductor and the cocatalytic function of ZnCoS possessing Zn (VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS) or S vacancies (VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS). The optimum VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS simultaneously exhibits a superior H2 production rate of 14.23 mmol h−1 g−1 accompanied with BAD formation rate of 12.29 mmol h−1 g−1 under visible-light irradiation, which is approximately two-fold greater than that of pristine ZnCdS. Under simulated sunlight irradiation (AM 1.5), VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS achieves H2 evolution (27.43 mmol gcat −1 h−1) with 0.52% of STH efficiency, accompany with 26.31 mmol gcat −1 h−1 of BAD formation rate. The underlying solar-driven mechanism is elucidated by a series of in-situ characterization and control experiments, which reveals the synergistic effect of interfacial ZB/WZ phase junctions in ZnCdS and S vacancies of ZnCoS on enhancement of the photoredox dual reaction. The VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS follows a predominant oxygen-centered radical integrating with carbon-centered radical pathways for BAD formation and a simultaneous electron-driven proton reduction for H2 production. Interestingly, the nature of surface vacancies not only facilitates the separation of photoinduced charge carriers but also able to selectively adjust the mechanism pathway for BAD production via tuning the oxygen-centered radical and carbon-centered radical formation. Graphical Abstract The dual-functional photoredox system harnesses solar energy for clean fuel production. Synergistic effects of ZnCdS phase junctions and surface vacancies of ZnCoS facilitate charge carrier separation and selectively adjust reaction pathways for optimal product formation. Keywords Photoredox dual reaction Aromatic alcohol conversion Surface vacancy Organic synthesis H2 production 1 Introduction Artificial photosynthesis with the utilization of solar energy appears as a prominent technology in chemical fuel production offering a green and sustainable paradigm for renewable energy systems in order to achieve low-carbon future [ 1,2 ]. Although solar-driven H2 evolution by water splitting has gained substantial interest from academic and industrial realms to produce green H2, the unsatisfied efficiency due to high overpotential, rapid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and sluggish reaction kinetics of the oxidative half-reaction still remains as the challenging setbacks restraining its potential application [ 3 ]. In this context, the majority of relevant research works focus on the employment of sacrificial agents into the system, namely, triethanolamine [ 4,5 ], sodium sulfide [ 6 ], ascorbic acid [ 7 ] and lactic acid [ 8 ], acting as hole scavenger to improve transport and separation efficiency of photoexcited carriers, thus accelerating the H2 generation. However, this approach results in undesired oxidation products and imposes the capital cost for H2 production [ 9 ]. Thus, developing an efficient system to simultaneously consume photoexcited electrons and holes to yield the corresponding green H2 (reduction product) and value-added oxidation product is essential for revolutionary solar energy utilization technologies. Oxidative conversion of biomass-derived alcohols (i.e., benzyl alcohol, furfuryl alcohol, cinnamyl alcohol) presents a crucial platform to provide primary intermediates as building blocks for fine bio-based chemicals production [ 10–12 ]. In recent years, solar-driven selective benzyl alcohol (BA) oxidation for benzaldehyde (BAD) synthesis using the photoinduced holes has attracted significant attention owing to its environmental friendliness but the requirement of additives and undesired hazardous waste has restrained its wide-ranging applications [ 13,14 ]. On this basis, photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation has recently emerged as an ideal strategy to effectively achieve the utilization of photoinduced electrons and holes, in which the proton can be reduced into clean H2 fuel while BA undergoes oxidation to form value-added BAD [ 15,16 ]. Therefore, it is imperative to design an efficient bifunctional heterogeneous photocatalyst capable of driving the consumption of both photoexcited electrons and holes to enable a high-performance cooperative photoredox coupling system. Metal sulfide semiconductors, particularly ternary zinc cadmium sulfide (ZnCdS) solid solution, have been widely investigated in photocatalysis activities owing to their adjustable band gap and edge position, excellent visible-light response and greatly resistant to photocorrosion [ 17,18 ]. To date, a twin crystal structure consisting of two distinctive crystalline phases, namely, zinc blende (ZB) and wurtzite (WZ) within ZnCdS composites has attracted vast attention. The existence of twin crystal structure within a nanocrystal purportedly presents a nano-scaled twin superlattice configuration with alternative arrangement of long-range-ordered twinned planes, which gives rise to unique WZ/ZB interphase junction, commonly referred to as homojunction, at specific dimensions [ 19 ]. The WZ/ZB interphase junction represents a type II staggered band in the twin superlattice configuration of the ZnCdS composites, which possesses interfacial electrostatic field resulting in excellent photoexcited charge carrier separation and the transport to specimen surface, hence facilitating redox reactions [ 20 ]. However, the ZnCdS composites with WZ/ZB interphase junction still suffer from rapid recombination of photoexcited electron-hole pairs which adversely affects the performance in photocatalytic activity [ 21 ]. Among the effective strategies, the incorporation of co-catalyst has appeared as a promising and facile solution to enhance the photocatalytic performance of ZnCdS-based semiconductors through enhanced transfer and separation efficiency towards photoinduced charge carriers [ 22–24 ]. Recently, ZnCoS material has been extensively studied in supercapacitors [ 25 ], electrocatalysis [ 26 ] and batteries [ 27 ] owing to its excellent structural stability and electrical conductivity. Nevertheless, the in-depth understanding of ZnCoS performance on photocatalysis activity is still little-known, especially to the effect of surface modification related to ZnCoS material on photocatalytic performance. Novel functional photocatalysts with optimal optoelectronic characteristics have been successfully developed by leveraging the distinct advantages of surface defect engineering, catering to the needs of sustainable energy and environmental applications. Factually, surface defect engineering in semiconductors leads to a higher absorption of visible light, formation of new catalytic active sites to prolong electron and hole lifetimes, hence dynamically improving the photocatalytic performance of photocatalysts [ 28 ]. The Zn vacancy sites reportedly act as hole trapping sites to accelerate the oxidation process whilst the S vacancy sites can serve as electron trapping sites for enhancing the reduction reaction [ 29–31 ]. However, the synergistic effect of twin crystal structure and the nature of surface vacancies on photoredox application have yet to be reported. In this context, the acquisition of surface vacancies (i.e., Zn or S vacancies) and ZnCdS with WZ/ZB phase junctions represents a viable approach to improve the activity of photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation for metal sulfide-based photocatalysts. Herein, we have prepared a series of ZnCdS-based photocatalysts, including pristine ZnCoS/ZnCdS without surface vacancies, Zn-vacancy ZnCoS/ZnCdS (VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS) and S-vacancy ZnCoS/ZnCdS (VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS). The photocatalytic behavior of well-characterized ZnCdS-based photocatalysts was studied and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS appeared as the best candidate of this series by possessing the highest H2 evolution, reaching nearly two-fold higher than that of ZnCoS/ZnCdS and a comparable BAD formation rate compared with VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. The kinetic characteristics of photogenerated charges significantly depend on the nature of surface vacancy sites, which determines their propensity to generate specific excessive charges for the respective products. Indeed, this property has a profound effect on the intrinsic photocatalytic activity of samples. Therefore, the primary objective of this study is to evaluate the effects of these properties on the performance of the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS catalyzed photoredox coupling reaction. The correlation between nature of S vacancies and ZB/WZ phase junctions of ZnCdS towards the photocatalytic behavior was systematically assessed and was rationalized to a bifunctional reaction mechanism, which entails the predominant oxygen-centered radical integrating with carbon-centered radical pathways for BAD formation and electron-driven proton reduction for H2 generation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, >98.0%), cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, 99.0%), Sodium sulfide hydrate (Na2S·xH2O, >60.0%), thioacetamide (CH3CSNH2, >98%), cadmium acetate dihydrate (Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O, >98%), ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, >99.0%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, >99.0%), benzyl alcohol (BA, >99%), triethanolamine (C6H25NO3, >99.0%), tert-butanol (C4H10O, >99.0%), potassium peroxodisulfate (K2S2O8, >99.0%), 5,5-dimethyl-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO, >98.0%), deionized water 18.2 MΩ cm. 2.2 Photocatalysts synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of pristine ZnCoS, Zn-vacancy ZnCoS and S-vacancy ZnCoS Pristine ZnCoS was produced with the employment of facile one-pot hydrothermal synthesis technique. Briefly, Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O:Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O: CH3CSNH2 with molar ratio of 1:2:4 were added into 40 mL aqueous solution of ethylene glycol and the mixed solution underwent an ultrasonic treatment for 0.5 h, followed by a stirring process for 4 h at ambient temperature for homogeneity. The mixed solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and subjected into an oven for heating at 180 °C for 12 h to carry out the hydrothermal process. The resultant products were collected by centrifugation and washed three times each with deionized water and ethanol, followed by drying inside an oven at 60 °C overnight. The solid powder was finally collected and denoted as ZnCoS. S-vacancy ZnCoS photocatalyst was synthesized through the similar abovementioned procedure with Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O: Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O:CH3CSNH2 molar ratio of 1:2:8. The resulting powder was denoted as VS-ZnCoS. The Zn-vacancy ZnCoS photocatalyst was prepared through a two-step synthesis approach, in which the hydrothermal method was followed by alkaline treatment. The as-synthesized pristine ZnCoS from the abovementioned approach was put into a 40 mL of 15 mol L−1 aqueous NaOH solution and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Then, it was subjected to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclaves and put inside an oven for 24 h at 180 °C. The resultant precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed three times each with deionized water and ethanol, followed by drying inside an oven at 60 °C overnight. The solid powder was finally collected and denoted as VZn-ZnCoS. 2.2.2 Synthesis of pristine ZnCdS, ZB-ZnCdS and WZ-ZnCdS The Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O:Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O:Na2S·xH2O: CH3CSNH2 with molar ratio of 1:1:2:2 were successively added into 40 mL deionized water and the mixture was ultrasonically treated for 0.5 h, followed by a stirring process lasted for 3 h. The 0.2 mol L−1 NaOH aqueous solution was added to adjust the mixture to around pH 7.0. The mixed solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and was heated inside an oven for 24 h at 180 °C. Subsequently, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and was washed three times each with deionized water and ethanol, followed by drying inside an oven at 60 °C overnight. The pure ZB-ZnCdS and WZ-ZnCdS were synthesized as reported elsewhere [ 17 ]. ZB-ZnCdS was prepared by coprecipitation method. The Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O:Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O with molar ratio of 1:1 were well dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water. The 0.2 mol L−1 NaOH aqueous solution was added to adjust the mixture to around pH 7.0. Subsequently, 30 mL of 0.3 mol L−1 Na2S·xH2O was added dropwise into the above mixture. The resulting mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature overnight. The precipitate was collected by centrifugation and was washed three times each with deionized water and ethanol, followed by drying inside an oven at 60 °C overnight. The pure WZ-ZnCdS was synthesized through a two-step strategy, in which coprecipitation and hydrothermal process. The coprecipitation process was similar to that of the abovementioned ZB-ZnCdS. The ZB-ZnCdS from coprecipitation was subsequently dispersed into 40 mL of deionized water through ultrasonication and stirring for 4 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was poured into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and was heated inside an oven for 12 h at 200 °C. The precipitate was collected by centrifugation and was washed three times each with deionized water and ethanol, followed by drying inside an oven at 60 °C overnight. 2.2.3 Preparation of ZnCoS/ZnCdS, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS The ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalyst was prepared via a conventional wetness impregnation approach. Briefly, 2 wt% ZnCoS and 98wt% ZnCdS were well dispersed into 40 mL deionized water through ultrasonication. The mixture solution was stirred for 4 h at ambient temperature and the supernatant was collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washed by deionized water and ethanol three times each, and then dried in air at 60 °C overnight. The VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS were prepared through a similar procedure by replacing the ZnCoS with Zn-vacancy ZnCoS and S-vacancy ZnCoS, respectively. 2.3 Characterizations X-ray diffractograms of specimens were collected within 2θ ranging of 10°–80° with 0.02° step size by Panalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα irradiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Textural properties of samples were determined through N2 physisorption measurement by Quantachrome Autosorb IQ-C-XR analyzer at –196 °C. Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed at 120 °C for 12 h. Morphologies studies were conducted by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images with the employment of JEOL JEM-2100F microscope installed with 200 kV field emission analytical electron microscope. Chemical states were determined by performing X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy with the Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD spectrometer operating at Al Kα X-ray radiation of 1486.69 eV. The obtained XPS spectra were normalized by the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV as the background reference. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were recorded on the Jasco V-770 UV-vis spectrometer with BaSO4 as the reflectance standard. Steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra of specimens were recorded using Shimadzu RF-6000 spectrofluorometer at 325 nm excitation wavelength. Zeta potential measurement was conducted by Anton Paar Litesizer 500 at room temperature to examine the surface charge of specimens. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) data were collected using a Bruker EMX-10/12 spectrometer at room temperature. In situ EPR analyses were performed to determine the reactive intermediate produced in the photocatalytic reaction with the use of 5,5-dimethyl-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as a radical-capturing agent. The signal of each specimen was recorded after 10 min of light irradiation. 2.4 Photoelectrochemical measurements All photoelectrochemical measurements were conducted at ambient temperature inside a standard three-electrode system on a Metrohm Autolab PGSTAT204 electrochemical workstation. The reference, counter and working electrodes were Ag/AgCl, Pt sheet and photocatalyst-coated thin film, respectively. The photocatalyst-coated thin film (working electrode) was prepared via a drop-casting method. Briefly, 10 mg catalyst, 200 μL ethanol and 40 μL Nafion were well mixed overnight. Subsequently, 40 μL of the subsequent ink solution was drop-casted onto fluorine-tin oxide (FTO) glass with an exposure area of 1 cm2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), Mott-Schottky (MS) and transient photocurrent response tests were conducted in 0.1 mol L−1 Na2SO4 electrolyte solution. EIS was measured under an open-circuit voltage with a frequency range from 10−2 to 105 Hz and a 10 mV AC amplitude. Mott-Schottky plots were collected at AC frequencies corresponded to 0.5, 1, and 1.5 kHz. The LSV measurements were performed at 10−2 V s−1 scan rate with 2 mV step size. Transient photocurrent responses tests were assessed under a simulated sunlight (320 λ λ λ 850 nm) from 300 W Xe lamp (CEL-PF300-T8, Beijing China Education Au-light (CEAuLight) Co., Ltd., 300 mW cm−2) at every 30 s light on/off time interval at 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The Nernst equation (Eq. (1)) is applied to convert the measured potential vs. Ag/AgCl into the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale in this study. (1) E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.059 × pH + E θ Ag/Cl where E θ Ag/Cl = 0.197 V at 25 °C. 2.5 Photocatalytic performance assessments 2.5.1 Photoredox dual reaction of benzyl alcohol oxidation and H2 production The photoredox dual reaction of H2 production and benzyl alcohol oxidation was conducted in a three-necked top-irradiation reactor cell. The as-synthesized 20 mg of photocatalyst was added into 60 mL benzyl alcohol aqueous solution (3 vol% benzyl alcohol) and the solution was ultrasonicated for 0.5 h. The reactor was treated with N2 purging for 0.5 h to entirely remove the air and then sealed. The reaction was conducted in a closed gas circulation system under irradiation (λ > 420 nm) with the employment of 300 W Xe lamp (CEL-PF300-T8, Beijing China Education Au-light (CEAuLight) Co., Ltd., 300 mW cm−2). The generated hydrogen was quantified by an online Agilent 8890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with mol sieve 5A and Hayesep Q columns as well as a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). After reaction, the suspension was filtered with a 0.22 μm nylon syringe filter and was analyzed by Acquity Arc Waters high-performance liquid chromatography system equipped with photodiode array detector and Kinetex 2.6 μm Phenyl-Hexyl 100 Å column. A mobile phase of water/acetonitrile (60:40) and dertection wavelength of 254 nm were employed to determine the composition of analyte. The apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) for H2 evolution was estimated based on the Eq. (2) at similar operating conditions with various band-pass filters, namely, 450, 500 and 550 nm. The corresponding average light intensities were recorded as 23.1, 26.8 and 34.8 mW cm−2. The irradiation area was about of 33.2 cm2. (2) AQE = N e N p × 2 × number of H 2 molecules number of incident photons × 100 % = 2 × n H 2 × h × c S × P × t × λ × 100 % where N e and N p correspond to the total reactive electrons and total incident photons. N A, h, c, S, P, t and λ represent Avogadro constant, Planck constant, light speed, irradiation area, average incident light intensity, reaction time and irradiation wavelength, respectively. The hydrogen evolution rate of photocatalysts under simulated sunlight irradiation was measured to estimate the solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency based on the Eq. (3). (3) STH ( % ) = R H 2 × Δ G H 2 P sun × S irr × 100 % where R H2, ΔG H2, P sun and S irr are corresponding to the H2 production efficiency, Gibbs free energy of water decomposition reaction (237.13 kJ mol−1 at 25 °C), the optical power density of incident sunlight (84.6 mW cm−2) and area of incident sunlight (33.18 cm2). Given that one molecule of benzaldehyde would be generated via the consumption of two photoinduced holes meanwhile releasing two protons. Subsequently, one H2 molecule would be produced through the consumption of two electrons and two protons. On this basis, the utilization rate (R U) ratio of photogenerated electrons relative to holes could be computed using Eq. (4). (4) R U = Numbers of evolved H 2 Numbers of formed benzaldehyde 2.5.2 Scavenger experiments for photocatalysis mechanism In order to gain insights into the reaction mechanism in the photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and benzyl alcohol oxidation, a series of active species and carrier capturing experiments were carried out. Equivalent scavenger agents (1 vol%), namely, triethanolamine (TEOA), potassium peroxodisulfate (K2S2O8) and diphenylamine (DPA) were used in the scavenger experiments. Typically, TEOA, K2S2O8 and DPA trap the corresponding holes, electron and oxygen-centered radical intermediate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural, morphological and surface chemistry studies Given the phase junctions of ZB and WZ of ZnCdS can enormously promote the efficiency of photoinduced charge carrier separation, the identification of such phases is crucial in this study. In this context, XRD analyses of pure ZB and pure WZ ZnCdS were conducted as shown in Fig. S1. All XRD patterns of specimens were analyzed by using JCPDS Database. For ZB ZnCdS sample, the XRD pattern was readily indexed to ZB ZnS (JCPDS card no. 05-0566) [ 17,32 ] and WZ CdS (JCPDS card no. 41-1049) [ 17,33 ], respectively. Notably, the peaks of ZB ZnCdS diffractogram were located between those of ZB ZnS and WZ CdS, implying the successful formation of ZnCdS solid solution [ 34 ]. After hydrothermal treatment, the WZ ZnCdS diffractogram depicts a transformation from ZB ZnCdS to WZ ZnCdS with dominant WZ CdS (JCPDS card no. 41-1049) [ 35 ], which possessed characteristic peaks at 25.7°, 27.5° and 31.5° corresponding to (100), (002) and (101) planes [ 36 ]. This crystallite structure could be a result of high-pressure-induced structural transformation. Considering a high-temperature hydrothermal treatment led to transformation of ZB to WZ phase of ZnCdS, a hydrothermal treatment with a lower temperature possibly yielding the coexistence of ZB/WZ phase junctions in pristine ZnCdS specimen. Although the diffraction peaks of WZ ZnCdS were absent in pristine ZnCdS diffractogram possibly due to low proportion and relatively poor crystallinity, the presence of ZB/WZ phase junctions was clearly observed in HRTEM results, which will be further discussed in the following section. Fig. 1(A ) displays the XRD patterns of pristine ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS, VS-ZnCoS, ZnCdS, and ZnCdS-based specimens. All ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS, VS-ZnCoS specimens exhibited poor crystallinity in XRD patterns and those diffraction peaks could be ascribed to the integration of ZB ZnS (JCPDS card no. 05-0566) [ 32 ] and ZnCoS (JCPDS card no. 47-1655) [ 37 ]. The similarity of these XRD patterns indicates that the surface modification to induce defect sites on ZnCoS has an insignificant influence on altering their structures. Generally, all ZnCdS-based photocatalysts display a similar XRD pattern to that of pristine ZnCdS owing to the low amount (2 wt%) addition of ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS and VS-ZnCoS specimens, implying their structural integrity. In general, the detected diffraction peaks in all ZnCdS-based photocatalysts samples were mainly attributed to ZB ZnS (JCPDS card no. 05-0566) [ 32 ] and WZ CdS (JCPDS card no. 41-1049) phases [ 35 ]. Particularly, the intensity of the distinctive peak at 27.5° for all ZnCdS-based photocatalysts was observably reduced with the addition of ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS and VS-ZnCoS. This implies the successful incorporation of ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS and VS-ZnCoS co-catalysts on pristine ZnCdS. Fig. S2 shows the N2 physisorption isotherms of ZnCoS/ZnCdS, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts. All the photocatalysts apparently demonstrated a type IV isotherm with H4-type hysteresis loop pattern, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure in the synthesized materials [ 38 ]. As seen in the inset in Fig. S2(A), all isotherms exhibited a two-step capillary condensation process at P/P 0 of about 0.3 and 0.9. In addition, the mesoporosity of photocatalysts is confirmed by their pore size distribution (Fig. S2(B)). All specimens demonstrated a similar pattern of pore size distribution within a range of 15–25 nm and 28–35 nm using BJH method, typical pore size presenting in mesostructured materials [ 39 ]. The BET surface area of ZnCoS/ZnCdS, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS were calculated as 12.94, 13.47 and 11.17 m2 g–1, respectively. The similarity of BET surface area of photocatalysts suggests that the physisorption attributes play an insignificant role in catalytic performance. In order to verify the existence of Zn or S vacancies, EPR measurements were conducted (Fig. 1(B)). There are no discernable paramagnetic signals for pristine ZnCdS spectra, indicating the absence of vacancy formation. Excluding pristine ZnCdS, two substantial paramagnetic signals attributed to S vacancies and adjacent excessive cations (i.e., Zn2+/Cd2+/Co2+) were discerned at g = 2.002 and 1.96, respectively, for all specimens [ 40 ]. Interestingly, the peak intensity of S vacancies was more pronounced towards VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS, illustrating that significant number of unpaired electrons were trapped in S vacancy sites. This stems from the agglomeration of excess S sources on nanocrystal surface which extensively impeded the crystallization process [ 19,41 ], leading to the successful formation of S vacancies on VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS surface. Notably, a discernible paramagnetic peak at g = 2.030 was exclusively detected in the VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS spectrum, aligning with the paramagnetic signal of zinc (Zn) vacancies [ 29 ]. This observation suggests that an optimal quantity of NaOH possessing strong alkali attributes could establish a robust reducing surrounding with comparatively low formation energy, thereby favoring the formation of zinc vacancies [ 42,43 ]. The EPR results corroborate the successful formation of S and Zn vacancies on VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS surface, respectively, in this study. These vacancy sites play essential roles in improved space-charge separation and enhanced kinetic properties of photogenerated charges, which would be further discussed in Section 3.4. Apart from formation of S and Zn vacancy sites, the presence of ZB/WZ phase junctions in ZnCdS represents another noteworthy aspect in this study. In this context, HRTEM measurements were performed for pristine ZnCdS and representative ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts (Fig. 2 ). The granular-nanostructure of pristine ZnCdS was evidently made up of nanoparticles possessing high crystallinity (Figs. 2(A)–(C)). As seen in Fig. 2(A), the HRTEM image of pristine ZnCdS exhibited a granular structure with lattice spacing of 0.32 and 0.36 nm indexed to the corresponding ZB (111) and WZ (100) crystal planes of ZnCdS [ 19 ]. Notably, ZB/WZ interphase boundaries were prominently observed, exhibiting a mirror-symmetric lattice (zigzag) pattern distributed on both sides of the twin boundaries. The presence of ZB/WZ interphase boundaries corroborates the formation of interfacial homogeneous junctions, which greatly affects the electronic properties of the ZnCdS and hence the enhancement of charge separation efficiency and transfer of charge carriers. From Fig. 2(B), the lattice fringe of 0.312 nm attributed to (002) crystal plane of ZnCoS was discerned in the HRTEM image of ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalyst [ 44 ], indicating the successful incorporation of ZnCoS with a low 2 wt% amount. Furthermore, it was identified at the specific location where a close interface contact was formed between ZB/WZ interphase boundaries (Fig. 2(C)). This would further promote the separation and migration of photo-induced carriers and subsequently lead to the improvement of photoactivity. To ascertain the chemical state and effect of vacancy sites on the surface chemistry of as-synthesized specimens, XPS measurements were performed as depicted in Fig. 3 and Fig. S3. In this section, the XPS discussion is segmented into two parts: (1) a comparison between pristine ZnCdS and ZnCoS/ZnCdS, and (2) a comparison between ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS or VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. In the former part, the pristine ZnCdS spectrum revealed that the binding energies of 1044.8 and 1021.8 eV in the Zn 2p region (Fig. 3(A)) were corresponding to the Zn 2p 1/2 and Zn 2p 3/2 [ 45 ]. In Cd 3d region (Fig. 3(B)), two peaks at 412.4 and 405.6 eV could be assigned to Cd 3d 3/2 and Cd 3d 5/2, respectively [ 19 ]. From Fig. 3(C), the S 2p region of pristine ZnCdS demonstrates two typical peaks corresponding to S 2p 1/2 and S 2p 3/2 at 162.7 and 161.2 eV [ 19 ]. Notably, all the above-mentioned binding energy peaks of ZnCoS/ZnCdS shifted to a lower binding energy region. This observation suggests an increase in electron density of ZnCdS surrounding due to electron transfer from ZnCoS, confirming the enhanced electronic properties of ZnCoS/ZnCdS. The comparison of XPS spectra between ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS (or VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS) affirmed the beneficial impact of surface defects on electronic properties of photocatalysts. In Zn 2p region (Fig. 3(A)), for VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS specimen, the Zn 2p 3/2 peak shifted to a lower binding energy location, illustrating an increase of electron density in Zn 2p of ZnCdS owing to the presence of Zn vacancies in VZn-ZnCoS. These Zn vacancies in VZn-ZnCoS could act as strong electron-deficient groups leading to a distortion in the electron cloud equilibrium of adjacent S atoms in ZnCdS framework [ 46 ]. This could be verified by the up-shifted S 2p 3/2 peak discerned in S 2p region of VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS (Fig. 3(C)), further corroborates the mobility of electrons from S atoms into Zn atoms of ZnCdS in VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. Conversely, for VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS specimen, the Zn 2p 3/2 peak substantially shifted to a higher binding energy position. In addition, a similar up-shifting pattern was observed in Cd 3d 5/2 peak (Fig. 3(B)) and S 2p 3/2 peak (Fig. 3(C)) of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. These observations indicate a reduction of surrounding electron density in ZnCdS, signifying the interfacial electron transfer from ZnCdS to VS-ZnCoS in VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. These S vacancies in ZnCoS would act as electron trapping sites leading to a nonstoichiometric coordinating environment for metal cations, thereby generating more active surface sites to benefit the photocatalytic activity [ 47,48 ]. Interestingly, such electron transfer phenomena in VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS are distinctively different with that of VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. This reveals that the electron mobility in composites could be largely affected by the nature of vacancy sites, which plays a crucial factor to not only optimize the photocatalytic performance but also to selectively determine the reaction mechanism. This will be further discussed in the following Section 3.5. These results are in well accordance with the EPR results, confirming the successful formation of Zn vacancies in VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and S vacancies in VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS in this study. 3.2 Photoabsorption properties and band structure studies The photoabsorption capabilities of pristine ZnCdS, VZn-ZnCoS, VS-ZnCoS, ZnCdS, and ZnCdS-based specimens were examined using UV-vis absorption (Fig. 4(A) ). The absence of absorption peak in ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS and VS-ZnCoS revealed they are non-semiconductor that unable utilizing solar to produce photogenerated electrons and holes for photoactivity. This speculation is verified by the transient photocurrent response analysis wherein no responsive signals were observed for these composites (Fig. S4). All the pristine ZnCdS and ZnCdS-based photocatalysts demonstrate a broad absorption band at wavelength ranging from 300 to 550 nm, confirming their visible-light-responsive properties [ 49,50 ]. Notably, the addition of ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS and VS-ZnCoS on ZnCdS specimen insignificantly altered the visible-light absorption capabilities in visible light region. Additionally, Urbach tails were observed in ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS spectra which probably owing to the electronic state lay inside the band gap [ 51,52 ], particularly to the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS possessing S vacancies. The band gap energy (E g) of pristine ZnCdS was estimated as 2.49 eV based on the Tauc plot in Fig. 4(B). Given the pristine ZnCdS consists of ZB/WZ phase junctions, the estimation of its band position is challenging due to the existence of interphases. On this basis, pure ZB ZnCdS and WZ ZnCdS samples were prepared to determine the corresponding conduction band (CB). From Fig. 5 , the pure ZB ZnCdS and WZ ZnCdS specimens endow positive slopes, typical characteristic of n-type semiconductors [ 53 ]. Based on the Mott-Schottky plots (Figs. 5(A) and (B)), the flat band potential (E f) of pure ZB ZnCdS and WZ ZnCdS were estimated as –0.69 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) and –0.79 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), respectively. Considering the Nernst equation, the E f of ZB ZnCdS and WZ ZnCdS corresponded to –0.1 V (vs. RHE) and –0.2 V (vs. RHE). The conduction band potential (E CB) of the n-type semiconductor is reportedly negative ~0.1 V than the E f [ 49 ] and hence, the E CB of ZB ZnCdS and WZ ZnCdS were computed as –0.2 V (vs. RHE) and –0.3 V (vs. RHE), correspondingly. Subsequently, the valence band potential (E VB) for ZB ZnCdS and WZ ZnCdS were estimated as 2.29 V (vs. RHE) and 2.19 V (vs. RHE), respectively based on the equation: E VB = E g + E CB. Fig. 5(C) illustrates the band structure schematic of pristine ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junctions. A type-II ZB/WZ phase junction in pristine ZnCdS is determined, which is aligned with the HRTEM image (Fig. 2(A)). The type-II staggered band alignment created in between the ZB and WZ fragments acts as a distinctive phase junction, which is propitious for achieving efficient charge migration and separation [ 17 ]. Notably, the reduction potential of H+/H2 (0 V vs. RHE) and oxidation potential of BA/BAD (1.98 V vs. RHE) falls within the band edge positions of pristine ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junction, affirming its excellent capability to conduct the photoredox dual reaction. 3.3 Photocatalytic performance Fig. 6(A ) demonstrates the H2 evolution obtained over the pristine ZnCdS and ZnCdS-based photocatalysts for photoredox dual reaction of BA oxidation and H2 production at 4 h-on-stream reaction run under visible light irradiation. All specimens showed a plateau H2 evolution after 2 h of visible light exposure, accredited to the ZB/WZ phase junction in ZnCdS leading to excellent photostability, which was in line with the transient photocurrent response results (Fig. 7(C) ). The incorporation of co-catalysts to ZnCdS system considerably enhanced the H2 evolution, in particular to the VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. In comparison with the pristine ZnCdS (6.46 mmol gcat –1 h–1), an increment around of 54.5% in H2 evolution could be achieved over VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS (9.98 mmol gcat –1 h–1) and most importantly, VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS demonstrated the highest H2 evolution which was about of two-fold higher, reaching 14.23 mmol gcat –1 h–1. Given these photocatalysts were assessed for photoredox dual reaction, their capabilities to yield oxidation co-product, BAD is of importance. Comparatively, both H2 and BAD formation rates were substantially improved for VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS with the presence of co-catalysts (Fig. 6(B)). All specimens showed a 99% selectivity of BAD which implies that BAD was the only oxidation product, accredited to the appropriate VB and CB positions of ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junctions (Fig. 5(C)) preventing the occurrence of over-oxidation of BAD into benzoic acid (2.50 V vs. RHE) [ 54 ]. To verify the effect of surface vacancies on photoredox capability of the specimen, the utilization rate (R U) ratio of photogenerated electrons involved in H2 evolution relative to photogenerated holes that participated in BAD formation was estimated (Fig. 6(B)). As the reference, the pristine ZnCdS exhibited a R U ratio of 0.81 which suggests that ZnCdS inherently favored the oxidation reaction. A similar trend is also observed for ZnCoS/ZnCdS with a R U ratio of 0.88, which highlights the cocatalytic function of ZnCoS in the improvement of photoexcited charge carrier separation contributing to the surface redox reaction. Notably, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS showed the lowest R U ratio (0.78) whilst the highest R U ratio (1.16) was attained over VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. The R U ratio of 0.78 for VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS indicates that the BA oxidation rate was facilitated owing to the excessive trapped holes in Zn vacancies. Conversely, the S vacancies in VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS captured excess electrons resulting in the acceleration of H2 formation rate as it is an electron-driven proton reduction process, achieving a R U ratio of 1.16. This observation affirms that the tuning nature of surface vacancies largely affects the photoredox capability of photocatalyst, which is the vital factor to realize an adjustable photoredox dual reaction application in this study. Among the photocatalysts, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS showed the highest BAD formation rate (12.78 mmol gcat –1 h–1), which was about of 55.47% increment compared to that of pristine ZnCdS (8.22 mmol gcat –1 h–1). Interestingly, VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibited a higher H2 formation rate than its BAD formation rate (12.29 mmol gcat –1 h–1) during the photoredox dual reaction whilst VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS showed an otherwise. This observation suggests that S vacancies in VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS favorably produced H2, predominantly owing to S vacancies acting as electron trapping sites prolonged the lifetime of excited electrons, hence facilitating the reduction of proton into H2 [ 55,56 ]. The Zn vacancies in VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS reportedly function as hole-trapping sites, thereby extending the lifespan of photoinduced holes and improving the oxidation of BA into BAD [ 29 ]. Additionally, these excellent photocatalytic performances of VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS were highly in accordance with the results of photogenerated charge carrier studies in Section 3.4, further corroborating the essential influence of the kinetics of photogenerated charge carriers on surface redox reaction. The mechanism of photogenerated charge carrier transfer over VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS will be further discussed in the following section. To further justify the photocatalytic activity of surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts for photoredox dual reaction of BA oxidation and H2 evolution, the product formation rates were compared with recently published reports (Table 1 ). Noticeably, the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS in this study showed remarkable H2 and BAD formation rates under visible light irradiation in comparison with other ternary metal sulfide systems or even noble metal-containing catalysts. This is attributed to the synergistic effect of ZB/WZ phase junctions and nature of surface vacancy sites in producing excessive charges to largely accelerate the respective redox reactions on catalyst surface. Since the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS appeared as the optimal photocatalyst with respect to the product formation rate at visible light region (> 420 nm), it was selected for further investigation of solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency under AM 1.5 simulated sunlight irradiation (Fig. 6(C)) and wavelength-dependent apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) calculation (Fig. 6(D)). As seen in Fig. 6(C), the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS showed a H2 evolution ranging from 25.94 to 32.90 mmol gcat –1 h–1 with 0.32% of STH efficiency after 18 h of exposure to simulated sunlight irradiation, accompany with 27.42 mmol gcat –1 h–1 of BAD formation rate. The performance of longevity was able to retain about 79% throughout the 18 h-on-stream reaction run. This reveals that VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS effectively utilizes the solar spectrum for H2 generation coupling with organic synthesis via photoconversion process, which highlights its potential wide-ranging applications in solar-driven conversion technology. Notably, the wavelength-dependent AQE values of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS followed its UV-Vis absorption trend. Particularly, the highest AQE around of 43.15% was achieved at 450 nm, corroborating its outstanding photo-absorption capability at visible light region. These results further demonstrate the significant improvement of photocatalytic performance over the synergistic effect between ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junctions and VS-ZnCoS by specifically modulation of the vacancy sites. Apart from BA, furfuryl alcohol (FA) was employed in this study to investigate the degree of universality for VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS towards wide-ranging photocatalytic applications. The VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS successfully catalyzed the photoredox dual reaction of furfuryl alcohol oxidation and H2 evolution. Interestingly, 556 µmol gcat –1 h–1 of H2 and 392 µmol gcat –1 h–1 of furfuraldehyde formation rates were demonstrated by VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS under a similar operation condition (Fig. S4). A higher R U value (1.42) was also observed in this case, highlighting the significant effect of electron trapping sites of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS on H2 production rate. 3.4 Mechanistic study of photogenerated charge carrier transfer In addition to the photoabsorption capability, the efficiency of photogenerated charge separation and migration plays a crucial role in the photocatalytic performance. Thus, a series of photoelectrochemical experiments were performed for pristine ZnCdS and ZnCdS-based photocatalysts, as depicted in Figs. 7(A)–(C). From the LSV profiles in Fig. 7(A), ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibited a relatively lower overpotential for H2 production compared with that of pristine ZnCdS, indicating an accelerated H2 evolution in the presence of ZnCoS [ 66 ]. Notably, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS showed a further reduced overpotential, corroborating an enormous positive effect of surface defects on H2 generation. This postulation is supplemented by EIS profiles (Fig. 7(B)) wherein the smallest arc radius of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS was observed followed by VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. This renders a lower interfacial charge-transfer resistance in the presence of surface vacancies that ensures a rapid charge migration and separation, thus contributing more charge carriers into photoredox dual reaction [ 67 ]. To gain insight into the photo-induced charge transfer effectiveness, transient photocurrent responses of all specimens were carried out. The absence of transient photocurrent responses signals of ZnCoS, VZn-ZnCoS and VS-ZnCoS co-catalysts corroborated that they are non-semiconductors under simulated sunlight exposure (Fig. S5). As displayed in Fig. 7(C), all pristine ZnCdS and ZnCdS-based photocatalysts demonstrate consistent photocurrent signals and reversible photo-responses under light on-off conditions for 10 cycles, indicating their excellent photo-stability [ 67 ]. Amongst the specimens, the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalyst exhibited the highest photocurrent intensity, followed by VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalyst. This suggests that the presence of surface vacancies not only enormously improves the light absorption to yield photogenerated excitons but also remarkably suppresses the charge recombination to improve the separation efficiency of excitons. To unravel the kinetics of photogenerated charge carriers for pristine ZnCdS and ZnCdS-based photocatalysts, the PL analyses were performed at an excitation wavelength of 325 nm (Fig. 7(D)). The ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibited an extensively reduced fluorescence intensity in comparison with that of pristine ZnCdS, indicating its excellent ability of suppression towards recombination of photo-induced charge carriers. Notably, lower fluorescence intensities were discerned over VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS specimens, which dictates that surface vacancies further restrain the photo-induced charge carrier recombination and hence effectively propelling the interfacial charge separation for photocatalytic activity [ 68,69 ]. The separation and transfer of photo-induced charge carriers are pivotal factors towards photocatalytic activity. Given that the ZnCdS possesses ZB/WZ phase junctions, the driving flow of photo-induced charge carriers at its interface for photoreaction is of interest. Combining the results of photo-absorption properties and band structure studies as well as photoelectrochemical experiments, the synergistic effect between ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junctions and VS-ZnCoS (or VZn-ZnCoS) on photogenerated carriers transfer mechanism for photoredox dual reaction of BA oxidation and H2 evolution is unraveled (Fig. 8 ). Under the sunlight irradiation, ZnCdS is excited to yield electrons in the CB of ZB and WZ phases while simultaneously creating holes in the VB of ZB and WZ phases. In the presence of type-II ZB/WZ phase junctions, the lifetime of photogenerated electron-hole pairs can be largely prolonged, thus enhancing the surface redox reaction. Specifically, the electrons and holes are accumulated at ZB and WZ phases in ZnCdS through the interphase junctions, respectively [ 18,19 ]. Based on the energy band structure studies, the E CB value of the ZB region (–0.20 V vs. RHE) is slightly more negative than the reduction potential of H+ into H2 whereas the E VB value of the WZ region (2.19 V vs. RHE) is relatively positive than the oxidation potential of BA into BAD. Consequently, these band positions of ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junctions endow it as an ideal candidate to ideally drive the photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation within a system. From the previous sections, the incorporation of co-catalysts significantly improved the photoelectrochemical properties of pristine ZnCdS, leading to their superior photocatalytic performance and stability. Although both VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibited similarly excellent performance, there is a difference in mechanism of photogenerated charge carrier transfer. For VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS, the Zn vacancies in ZnCoS act as hole trapping sites resulting in the migration of holes from the WZ segment in ZnCdS to Zn vacancies in ZnCoS, which further extends the lifetime of photogenerated holes and subsequently enhances their degree of participation in the BA oxidation to produce BAD (Fig. 8). As a result, a higher BAD formation rate was observed compared to that of H2 over VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS (Fig. 6(B)). Conversely, VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS inferred a higher H2 formation rate than that of BAD. This is attributed to the role of S vacancies in ZnCoS as electron trapping sites, where the photo-induced electrons transfer from ZB segment of ZnCdS into S vacancies in ZnCoS, thereby prolonging the lifetime of photogenerated electrons to improve their extent of involvement in the H2 production (Fig. 8). In addition, these surface vacancies enormously promote the transportation of photogenerated charge carriers from bulk to surface, as evidenced by results of photoelectrochemical experiments (Figs. 7(A)–(C)). Hence, the modification of nature of vacancy sites on ZnCoS co-catalysts remarkably leads to a substantial alteration in mechanism of photogenerated charge carrier transfer. This casts a novel idea to optimize the design of dual-functional photocatalysts for cooperative H2 generation and organic synthesis. 3.5 Mechanistic study of photoredox dual reaction Apart from the transfer-separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers from bulk to photocatalyst surface, the photocatalytic performance associated with the surface reaction kinetic is highly concerned to elucidate insights into the underlying mechanism of photoredox dual reaction of BA oxidation and H2 evolution in this study. The BA adsorption is the very crucial first step to initiate the oxidation half-reaction. The zeta potentials of ZnCoS/ZnCdS, VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts were examined as –7.32, –8.49 and –10.24 mV, respectively (Fig. S6). The highest negative surface electricity of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS reveals its propensity of BA adsorption on catalyst surface induced by electrostatic interaction in comparison with others, which facilitates the reaction process [ 66 ]. This was in line with the trend in photocatalytic performance of specimens. A series of control experiments focused on the participation of the active species in the reaction mechanism were conducted. Triethanolamine (TEOA) was employed as a quenching agent for photo-induced holes to investigate the role of holes in the conversion of BA into BAD. As seen in Figs. 9(A) and (B ), the H2 formation rates were almost unchanged over both VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts in comparison with their photocatalytic activity without the addition of scavenger agent. However, the BAD formation rates were observably reduced around 36.3% over VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and 45.6% over VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS, implying that photo-induced holes only participated in the formation of BAD. The lower degree of reduction in BAD formation rate for VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS was accredited to the excessive Zn vacancies trapping abundant holes, which considerably counteracted the adverse effect of hole consumption caused by TEOA. When potassium peroxodisulfate (K2S2O8) was used to capture the photogenerated electrons, the H2 formation rates of both VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts were drastically suppressed about of 93.1% and 87.2%, respectively whereas their corresponding BAD formation rates were slightly reduced. Such observation reveals that the H2 evolution is directly attained through the electron-driven proton reduction process [ 70,71 ]. In addition, the negative effect due to electron consumption by K2S2O8 was slightly hampered by S vacancies in VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS where accumulated excessive photogenerated electrons. Regardless of the type of photocatalyst, both H2 and BAD formation rates were evidently suppressed in the existence of the corresponding scavenger agents. Notably, the degree of reduction in the BAD yield rate (36.3%–45.6%) was substantially lighter than that of the H2 yield rate (87.2%–93.1%), indicating that the BAD formation proceeds through radical intermediates [ 71 ]. Hence, the photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation undergoes a radical-initiated reaction mechanism route. To gain more insights into the radical-initiated reaction mechanism of photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation, in situ EPR analysis was conducted with the employment of DMPO as a radical-trapping agent (Fig. 10(A) and (B )). Based on the literature [ 72,73 ], Cα–H bonds and hydroxyl groups (–OH) are preferentially activated during the transformation of BA into BAD, thereby leading to the production of active radical intermediates, namely, carbon-centered (Cα) and oxygen-centered radicals, respectively. Under visible light irradiation, the characteristic weak sextet peaks of DMPO-Cα radical (Fig. 10(A)) and signal of DMPO-•OH radical (Fig. 10(B)) were discerned for pristine ZnCdS. Although the detectable signals were considerably weak, the visible-light-responsive ZnCdS is undeniably capable of converting the BA into BAD via radical-initiated reaction pathways. As demonstrated by the ZnCoS/ZnCdS spectrum, the signals of DMPO-Cα radical and DMPO-•OH radical were remarkably enhanced with the incorporation of ZnCoS co-catalyst, in particular to the DMPO-•OH radical signal. This highlights that the formation rate of radical intermediates is correlated to the kinetics of photogenerated charge carriers. The strong signal of DMPO-•OH radical over ZnCoS/ZnCdS indicates that a large amount of free •OH radicals were generated in the reaction system. In fact, BAD can be further oxidized into undesired benzoic acid under •OH radical-rich environment [ 73 ]. Thus, excessive free •OH radicals are inappropriate to the selective oxidation of BA into BAD. Interestingly, the surface vacancy modification on ZnCoS co-catalyst in both VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS is found to significantly suppress the formation of these •OH radicals (Fig. 10(B)). Since no benzoic acid is detected during the reaction, •OH radicals have an insignificant impact on the BA oxidation process and are assumably adsorbed on the catalyst surface instead of present in the solution as free •OH radicals [ 73,74 ]. This is supplemented by the calculated energy band structure of both VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS (Fig. 8). Based on the calculation, the over-oxidation of BAD is thermodynamically unfavorable as the oxidation potential of BA/oxidized BAD (2.50 V vs. RHE) is more positive than the VB position of ZnCdS with ZB/WZ phase junctions. From Figs. 10(A) and (B), both VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS showed stronger signals of DMPO-Cα radical and reduced signals of DMPO-•OH radical, indicating that the surface vacancy sites not only facilitate the Cα–H bond cleavage in BA molecules but also enormously suppress the formation of •OH radicals to prevent the over-oxidation of BA. Notably, the VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibited a higher signal of DMPO-Cα radical compared to that of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS, highlighting the significance of excessive photogenerated holes in facilitating the carbon-centered radical intermediate formation. Additionally, scavenger tests of oxygen-centered radical for VZn-ZnCoS/ ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS (Figs. 9(A) and (B)) were performed with the introduction of DPA, aiming to unveil deeper insights into potential intermediate processes. The BAD formation rates were reduced by about 20.9% over VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and 44.3% over VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. This reveals that oxygen-centered radical intermediate plays an essential role in the photocatalytic BA oxidation and this effect is more pronounced on the VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS. Based on the results of the scavenger experiment and in situ EPR analysis, it is evident that both carbon-centered radical and oxygen-centered radical intermediates exert significant impacts on the photocatalytic performance of VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS and VS-ZnCoS/ ZnCdS, suggesting the co-occurrence of carbon-centered radical and oxygen-centered radical pathways during the reaction. However, there is a difference between their respective mechanism, in which VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS follows a dominant carbon-centered radical pathway whereas VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS conceivably endows a dominant oxygen-centered radical route for photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation. Given that H2 is the primary product followed by BAD in this study, the reaction mechanism on VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS is of our primary interest. On this basis, we propose a predominant oxygen-centered radical integrating with carbon-centered radical pathways for the photoredox dual reaction of H2 evolution and BA oxidation over VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalyst (Fig. 11 ). Under the visible-light irradiation, ZnCdS is excited to yield electron-hole pairs which are effectively separated by the presence of ZB/WZ phase junctions. Specifically, the photogenerated electrons (e−) and holes (h+) are separated and subsequently localized in the ZB and WZ phases, respectively, according to the type II staggered band in the WZ/ZB interphase junction transfer path driven by the built-in electric field. In addition, the incorporation of VS-ZnCoS further induces the interfacial electron transfer and trapping these photogenerated electrons in S vacancies, thus enormously enhancing the separation efficiency of photo-induced charge carriers. The adsorption of the –OH bond in BA molecules on the catalyst surface is the very first step to initiate the dehydrogenation process, which yields alkoxide anions (PhCH2O−) and extractive protons [ 75 ]. The PhCH2O− is readily oxidized by photogenerated holes in the ZnCdS via attacking the Cα–H bonds to induce carbon-centered radical route (Path A) or O− sites to originate oxygen-centered radical route (Path B). For VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS, the O− sites in PhCH2O− are preferentially attacked by holes to activate oxygen-centered radical intermediates which subsequently react with photoinduced holes to produce desired BAD products via the dehydrogenation step. In another route, the photogenerated holes in ZnCdS likely attack the Cα–H bond in PhCH2O− to form carbon-centered radical intermediates and the resultant protons are adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The resulting carbon-centered radical intermediates successively react with holes to undergo oxidation toward the formation of BAD. Meanwhile, the photogenerated electrons reduce the protons resulted from BA or water to simultaneously produce gaseous H2 products. 4 Conclusions The surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalysts with ZB/WZ phase junctions and surface vacancy sites (i.e., VZn or VS) have been successfully designed to act as robust dual-functional photocatalysts for photoredox coupling of benzyl alcohol oxidation and H2 evolution. The driving force from the built-in electric field due to the existence of WZ/ZB interphase junction contributes to excellent charge transfer separation during photocatalytic reaction. The photogenerated charge carrier transfer studies reveal that the construction of VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS further enhances the charge transfer and separation efficiency due to the electron trapping effect of S vacancies, which facilitates the surface redox reaction, particularly to the H2 generation. As a result, VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibits a remarkable H2 evolution rate about two-fold higher than its counterpart, attaining 14.23 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and the BAD formation rate reaches 12.29 mmol gcat −1 h−1, demonstrating an extraordinary photocatalytic performance under visible light irradiation. While VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS exhibits a greater BAD formation rate than that of H2 due to the hole trapping effect induced by Zn vacancies, which considerably enhances BA oxidation process. Specifically, the built-in electric field of twin crystal structure in ZnCdS promotes the efficiency of photoinduced charge carrier separation. The Zn and S vacancies individually act as hole and electron trapping sites to benefit the BAD and H2 production, respectively. The in situ EPR and scavenger experiments affirm the co-occurrence of carbon-centered radical and oxygen-centered radical pathways for BA transformation into BAD. Notably, this study reveals that a preferential mechanism pathway could be achieved through dominantly selective radical activation associated with the nature of surface vacancy on the catalyst. On this basis, we propose the dual-functional VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS photocatalyst follows a predominant oxygen-centered radical integrating with carbon-centered radical pathways for BAD formation and a simultaneous electron-driven proton reduction for H2 production. This study highlights the inaugural utilization of surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS materials for the synergistic integration of H2 production and anaerobic selective organic synthesis. Overall, this work offers a novel strategy and casts new insights into designing multifunctional noble-metal-free all-sulfide-based photocatalytic systems for photoredox applications by tuning the mechanism routes in association with selective radical activation. coredata.dc:description: Photoredox dual reaction of organic synthesis and H2 evolution opens up a novel pathway for collaboratively generating clean fuels and high-quality chemicals, providing a more effective approach of solar energy conversion. Herein, a surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS heterostructure with zinc blende (ZB)/wurtzite (WZ) phase junctions is synthesized for photocatalytic cooperative coupling of benzaldehyde (BAD) and H2 production. This surface defect-engineered ZnCoS/ZnCdS heterostructure elaborately integrates the mixed phase junction advantage of ZnCdS semiconductor and the cocatalytic function of ZnCoS possessing Zn (VZn-ZnCoS/ZnCdS) or S vacancies (VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS). The optimum VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS simultaneously exhibits a superior H2 production rate of 14.23 mmol h−1 g−1 accompanied with BAD formation rate of 12.29 mmol h−1 g−1 under visible-light irradiation, which is approximately two-fold greater than that of pristine ZnCdS. Under simulated sunlight irradiation (AM 1.5), VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS achieves H2 evolution (27.43 mmol gcat −1 h−1) with 0.52% of STH efficiency, accompany with 26.31 mmol gcat −1 h−1 of BAD formation rate. The underlying solar-driven mechanism is elucidated by a series of in-situ characterization and control experiments, which reveals the synergistic effect of interfacial ZB/WZ phase junctions in ZnCdS and S vacancies of ZnCoS on enhancement of the photoredox dual reaction. The VS-ZnCoS/ZnCdS follows a predominant oxygen-centered radical integrating with carbon-centered radical pathways for BAD formation and a simultaneous electron-driven proton reduction for H2 production. Interestingly, the nature of surface vacancies not only facilitates the separation of photoinduced charge carriers but also able to selectively adjust the mechanism pathway for BAD production via tuning the oxygen-centered radical and carbon-centered radical formation.
